H0.text: The hottest layers are closest to the core is the best description of the relationship between Earth's layers.

H1.text: The more liquid layers are closest to the crust best describes the relationship between Earth's layers.

H2.text: The lightest layers are closest to the core is the best description of the relationship between Earth's layers.

H3.text: The more metallic layers are closest to the crust, best describing the relationship between Earth's layers.

A4.text: Earth's outer core is a fluid layer about 2,260 km in height and composed of mostly iron and nickel.

A5.text: Earth's outer core lies above Earth's solid inner core and below its mantle.

A6.text: The temperature at its surface is estimated to be approximately 5,700 K (5,430 °C; 9,800 °F), about the temperature at the surface of the Sun.

A7.text: The inner core is solid at high temperature because of its high pressure, in accordance with the Simon-Glatzel equation.
